docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13--The Food and Drug Administration proposed today to give food, drug, cosmetic and color manufacturers additional time to test the safety of 23 color additives used in substances from face cream to ice cream.

headline.main: F.D.A. Backs Deadline Extension For Testing of 23 Color Additives; 'Unavoidable Delays' in Testing

docs.abstract: FDA proposes to give food manufacturers additional time to test safety of color additives (M)
docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13--The Food and Drug Administration proposed today to give food, drug, cosmetic and color manufacturers additional time to test the safety of 23 color additives used in substances from face cream to ice cream.

byline.original: By KAREN DE WITT Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: Bills that would extend the state's 5 percent sales tax to gasoline to help pay for road and bridge repairs and use the Casino Tax Fund indirectly to help meet a $50 million shortfall in Medicaid are being prepared by two members of Governor Byrne's cabinet. In separate news conferences today, Louis J. Gambaccini, the State Transportation Commissioner, and Ann Klein, the Commissioner of Human Resources, detailed their needs, with Mrs. Klein stressing that additional funds were needed to prevent the medicaid program from going bankrupt by next May.

headline.main: TRENTON GETTING BILL TERMED A WAY TO PREVENT BANKRUPTCY OF MEDICAID

docs.lead_paragraph: TRENTON, Nov. 13--Bills that would extend the state's 5 percent sales tax to gasoline to help pay for road and bridge repairs and use the Casino Tax Fund indirectly to help meet a $50 million shortfall in Medicaid are being prepared by two members of Governor Byrne's cabinet.

headline.main: Trenton Getting Bill Termed a Way To Prevent Bankruptcy of Medicaid; Medicaid Cutbacks Announced

docs.abstract: Bill will be introduced in NJ Legislature on Nov 24 that provides for use of casino tax funds indirectly to meet expected $50 million shortfall in Medicaid program; Human Resources Comr Ann Klein expects Medicaid program to run out of funds by May unless additional money is forthcoming, news conf; announces series of program cutbacks; Gov Byrne is sympathetic, but chances of passing new tax measure after Jan appear slim (M)

byline.original: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration proposed today to give food, drug, cosmetic and color manufacturers additional time to test the safety of 23 color additives used in substances from face cream to ice cream. Results of the tests, the earliest of which is now scheduled to be completed by October 1981, will be used by the agency to determine whether a color additive should be approved for permanent use or be withdrawn from the market because it is unsafe for its intended use. The original deadline for the testing results was Jan. 31, 1981.

headline.main: F.D.A. BACKS EXTENSION FOR TESTING OF 23 COLOR ADDITIVES

docs.lead_paragraph: AGROAN from a young man in the church pew behind me abruptly stopped the wedding service and drew my attention. I believed he was experiencing a grand mal epileptic seizure, and I went to his side to help him avoid injury. Although injuries during a seizure are unusual, seizure victims have suffered broken teeth, broken limbs and even severe head injuries. The man was unconscious. The contracted muscles throughout his body twitched violently. His hands were held fixed like claws. If we were in an emergency room, drugs like Valium and Dilantin could be injected into a vein to halt the seizure. But the man was on a church bench. His legs, rigid, were stretched under the pew. The narrow space made it difficult to maneuever, but several other wedding guests helped me move him to the aisle. We placed a jacket under his head as a pillow. We sought information from the man's parents or friends, but no one responded.

headline.main: PILLS AND THE PROCESS OF GOVERNMENT

docs.abstract: Article on controversy surrounding FDA regulation, issued on Sept 10 '80, requiring druggists to provide patients with package inserts giving information on proper use, side effects and risks of 10 kinds of commonly used prescription drugs; portraits of Louis A Morris, Dr Jere E Goyan (FDA), Repr Bill Alexander, George C Eads (Regulatory Analysis Group) and Esther Peterson (Consumer Affairs) (L)
docs.snippet: It was the routine kind of event that passes with little more than perfunctory press notice every day in official Washington. On Sept. 10, the Federal Government issued a new regulation: By order of ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Robert Reinhold is a reporter in the Washington bureau of The New York Times. By Robert Reinhold It was the routine kind of event that passes with little more than perfunctory press notice every day in official Washington. On Sept. 10, the Federal Government issued a new regulation: By order of the Food and Drug Administration, druggists would be compelled to provide leaflets giving basic information on the proper use, side effects and risks of 10 kinds of commonly used - and misused -prescription drugs.
